ul_14728: ls -ltcr         # sort by and show change time, most recent last

Explanations about Options.-k: sort via a key; KEYDEF gives location and type

Answers.MP Summary: output the first part of files
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Output everything but the last few lines of a file
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_3302900: How to Sort Output from several Log Files by date
au_23688: Best way to list 100 first files in a directory sorted by time
su_416308: How to list files recursively and sort them by modification time?
Top-3 Scripts:
au_23688: ls -cr | head -n 100

find . -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec stat -c $'%Z\t%n' '{}' \; |
    sort -k 1n |
    cut -f 2 -d $'\t' |
    head -n 10 |
    sed -e 's/^\.\///'

find . -mindepth 1 -maxdepth 1 -exec stat -c $'%W\t%n' '{}' \; |
    sort -k 1n |
    cut -f 2 -d $'\t' |
    head -n 10 |
    sed -e 's/^\.\///'
su_416308: find . -type f -exec stat -f "%m%t%Sm %N" '{}' \; | sort -rn | head -20 | cut -f2-

Explanations about Options.-n:
print the first NUM lines instead of the first 10; with the leading '-', print all
 but the last NUM lines of each file
